title: Mike Kuiti
text:
Michael James Kuiti (born 18 March 1963 in <a href="Foxton%2C%20New%20Zealand">Foxton, New Zealand</a>) is a New Zealand <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> player who played professionally in England and represented <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a>, including in test matches that counted towards the <a href="1992%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1992 World Cup</a>. Currently living in Lower Hutt, New Zealand.
Playing career.
Kuiti was a member of the Upper Hutt club in the <a href="Wellington%20Rugby%20League">Wellington Rugby League</a> competition, making his senior début in 1980. He was part of premiership wins in 1986 and 1987. Kuiti played for the club until 1992, becoming club captain.
On 8 January 1990 Kuiti signed with the <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds club</a>. He spent three seasons at the club before joining <a href="Rochdale%20Hornets">Rochdale Hornets</a>. Mike Kuiti played, and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in <a href="Rochdale%20Hornets">Rochdale Hornets</a> 14-24 defeat by <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> in the <a href="1991%20Lancashire%20Cup">1991</a> <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1991%E2%80%9392%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1991–92 season</a> at <a href="Wilderspool%20Stadium">Wilderspool Stadium</a>, <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a>, on Sunday 20 October 1991. Kuiti then spent three years at <a href="Oldham%20R.L.F.C.">Oldham</a> (<a href="List%20of%20Oldham%20R.L.F.C.%20players">Heritage № 1012</a>) before joining <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> (<a href="Captain%20%28sports%29">captain</a>) (<a href="List%20of%20Wakefield%20Trinity%20players">Heritage № 1075</a>) in 1996. Kuiti also played for the <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley Bulldogs</a> and <a href="Swinton%20Lions">Swinton Lions</a>.
Representative career.
Kuiti represented <a href="Wellington%20rugby%20league%20team">Wellington</a>, making his début in 1981. Kuiti went on to play in 59 games for Wellington and is the sixth highest capped player. He played for <a href="Central%20Districts%20rugby%20league%20team">Central Districts</a> four times between 1984 and 1987 and also played for <a href="New%20Zealand%20M%C4%81ori%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand Māori</a>, including at the <a href="1986%20Pacific%20Cup">1986 Pacific Cup</a>.
Kuiti made his long-awaited <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand national rugby league team</a> début on the <a href="1989%20New%20Zealand%20rugby%20league%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1989 tour of Great Britain and France</a>. He played in eleven games on tour, including two test wins over <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">France</a>. He was dropped in 1990 for home tests against <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> before being reinstated for the <a href="1990%20New%20Zealand%20rugby%20league%20tour%20of%20Papua%20New%20Guinea">1990 tour of Papua New Guinea</a>. He finished his international career with two tests against the touring <a href="1992%20Great%20Britain%20Lions%20tour%20of%20Australasia">Great Britain Lions in 1992</a>.
Coaching career.
Kuiti was the head coach of the <a href="Porirua%20Pumas">Porirua Pumas</a> in the <a href="2000%20Bartercard%20Cup">2000 Bartercard Cup</a>.
In 2010 Kuiti was the coach of the <a href="Hutt%20International%20Boys%27%20School">Hutt International Boys' School</a> side in the <a href="Wellington%20Rugby%20League">Wellington Rugby League</a>'s <a href="Stephen%20Kearney">Stephen Kearney</a> Cup.
He coached the <a href="Wellington%20Orcas">Wellington Orcas</a> in the 2013 <a href="National%20Competition">National Competition</a>.
Legacy.
In 2012 he was named in the <a href="Wellington%20Rugby%20League">Wellington Rugby League</a>'s Team of the Century.
